repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

comment_data.body:
Nit:
```suggestion
  -- Lua 5.1 does not have __len metamethod so we need to provide a len()
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,76 @@
+-- Basic shim for LuaJIT's stringbuffer.
+-- Note this does not implement the full API.
+local M = {}
+
+local has_strbuffer, strbuffer = pcall(require, 'string.buffer')
+
+if has_strbuffer then
+  M.new = strbuffer.new
+
+  -- Lua 5.1 does not have __len metamethod so we need to provdie a len()

comment_data.body: I had not realized that Lua hoisted types such that you can reference this type even if you define it below. Neat.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,76 @@
+-- Basic shim for LuaJIT's stringbuffer.
+-- Note this does not implement the full API.
+local M = {}
+
+local has_strbuffer, strbuffer = pcall(require, 'string.buffer')
+
+if has_strbuffer then
+  M.new = strbuffer.new
+
+  -- Lua 5.1 does not have __len metamethod so we need to provdie a len()
+  -- function to use instead.
+
+  --- @param buf vim._stringbuffer

comment_data.body: Nit: For better docs/LSP support, I would add the return annotation too.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,76 @@
+-- Basic shim for LuaJIT's stringbuffer.
+-- Note this does not implement the full API.
+local M = {}
+
+local has_strbuffer, strbuffer = pcall(require, 'string.buffer')
+
+if has_strbuffer then

+  -- Lua 5.1 does not have __len metamethod so we need to provdie a len()
+  -- function to use instead.
+
+  --- @param buf vim._stringbuffer

comment_data.body: This implementation will be called with `print()` right? If so, I think it's quite unexpected for it to modify internal state.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,76 @@
+-- Basic shim for LuaJIT's stringbuffer.
+-- Note this does not implement the full API.
+local M = {}
+
+local has_strbuffer, strbuffer = pcall(require, 'string.buffer')
+
+if has_strbuffer then
+  M.new = strbuffer.new
+
+  -- Lua 5.1 does not have __len metamethod so we need to provdie a len()
+  -- function to use instead.
+
+  --- @param buf vim._stringbuffer
+  function M.len(buf)
+    return #buf
+  end
+
+  return M
+end
+
+--- @class vim._stringbuffer
+--- @field private buffer string[]
+--- @field private skip_ptr integer
+--- @field package len integer
+local StrBuffer = {}
+StrBuffer.__index = StrBuffer
+
+--- @return string
+function StrBuffer:tostring()

comment_data.body: It's unclear what `msg` is referring to here.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -16,102 +16,49 @@ local function format_message_with_content_length(message)
   })
 end
 
----@class (private) vim.lsp.rpc.Headers: {string: any}
----@field content_length integer
-
---- Parses an LSP Message's header
+--- Extract content-length from the msg header

comment_data.body:
`tostring()` requires `table.concat` and would defeat the point if the module did not save that computation.

https://luajit.org/ext_buffer.html mentions:

>  Creates a string from the buffer data, but doesn't consume it. The buffer remains unchanged. 

You could argue this is _changing_ the buffer, but it's not consuming it, or changing the content, just normalizing the _internal_ structure.

We could break this out into a `_normalize()` method, but I don't really see the point.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,76 @@
+-- Basic shim for LuaJIT's stringbuffer.
+-- Note this does not implement the full API.
+local M = {}
+

+
+if has_strbuffer then
+  M.new = strbuffer.new
+
+  -- Lua 5.1 does not have __len metamethod so we need to provdie a len()
+  -- function to use instead.
+
+  --- @param buf vim._stringbuffer
+  function M.len(buf)
+    return #buf
+  end
+
+  return M
+end
+
+--- @class vim._stringbuffer
+--- @field private buffer string[]
+--- @field private skip_ptr integer
+--- @field package len integer
+local StrBuffer = {}
+StrBuffer.__index = StrBuffer
+
+--- @return string
+function StrBuffer:tostring()

comment_data.body: LuaLS can infer the return type here, and this module isn't documented.

comment_data.body: I still like to explicitly add the return type to ensure I always return from all branches (in case this function gets more complicated in the future).

comment_data.body: Fair enough. Could we maybe add a comment explaining why this `tostring` implementation has side effects?

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
-- Note this does not implement the full API.
-- This is intentionally internal-only. If we want to expose it, we should ship
-- it as `string.buffer` (minus the FFI stuff) for Lua 5.1.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,106 @@
+-- Basic shim for LuaJIT's stringbuffer.
+-- Note this does not implement the full API.

comment_regular_data.body: This is a just light shim around LuaJITs `string.buffer` module which is already available to users. I did not intend this shim to ever be exposed.

Ok, but that means users/plugins will have to create the same kind of wrapper if we don't expose this. 

That doesn't mean we need to "intend" anything in this PR, but the name will be sticky so would prefer to mimic ringbuf meanwhile.
Yes, but this makes it actually usable -- if even a single plugin didn't want to use it because it was not available on all platforms, this will be helpful. (We shim bit, too, after all.)

Keep in mind that the LuaJIT version supports the `#` operator which I've had to workaround here in a slightly ugly way.

So if we expose anything, I'd prefer this is reimplemented as userdata so we can maintain the same interface (and avoid the `#` footgun), and even potentially ship it as `string.buffer` (minus the FFI stuff).

repo.name: neovim

title: perf(lsp): improve rpc loop performance (with shim)
